text: Bayt Lif () is a village in the Bint Jbeil District in southern Lebanon. ==Name== According to E. H. Palmer, the name means "the house of lif" (palm- fibre).Palmer, 1881, p. 68 ==History== In 1852, Edward Robinson noted that the year before, a quantity of gold coin were found at Beit Lif, which was taken to Beirut and given to the Pasha. He further noted that the people were planting millet and tobacco.Robinson and Smith, 1856, p. 62 In 1875, Victor Guérin found here a village with 80 Metuali inhabitants.Guérin, 1880, pp. 415-416 In 1881, the PEF's Survey of Western Palestine (SWP) described it as: "A village, built of stone, containing about 150 Moslems [..] situated on a hill-top, with a few olives and arable land. Two cisterns and a birket near supply the water."Conder and Kitchener, 1881, SWP I, p. 201 ==References== ==Bibliography== * * * * ==External links== * Beit Lif, Localiban *Survey of Western Palestine, Map 4: IAA, Wikimedia commons Category:Populated places in Nabatieh Governorate Category:Bint Jbeil District Category:Shia Muslim communities in Lebanon
title: Bayt Lif
